Fun fact: Stainless steel is an alloy of steel and chromium. It's corrosion resistant because the chromium produces a transparent oxide layer, and because of it, stainless steel is going to say "no" to many forms of torture, chemicals included. It's the main reason it's a common and popular metal. Guess what else chromium is (and was) used for...

Turn a penny gold with NaOH, zinc, an evaporating dish, and a hot plate. NaOH and zinc go into the evaporating dish that goes on the hot plate. When it begins to boil stick the penny in the boiling mixture and watch it turn silver. Then, wash the silver penny off and put it directly onto the hot plate and watch it turn to a gold color. Finally, wash it off again and it will become a shinny gold color instantly. Very fun and satisfying and highly recommended. Have fun!

So, I feel obligated to say if you can do this why not make a voltaic cell. Electroplating is very similar to making a voltaic cell. To make a primary voltaic cell you need copper(II)sulfate (aq), copper, zinc sulfate (aq), zinc, 2 non-metal containers, a tube to connect the solutions, cotton to plug the tube, and sodium chloride (aq). Fill the containers with the different sulfate solutions. Put each metal into the containers with their matching sulfates, copper with CuSO4 zinc with ZnSO4. Plug the tube ends with cotton and fill the tube with the sodium chloride solution. Connect the containers to the tube. Connect the metals with the wires and the reaction will begin. The copper (cathode)  wants the electrons more than the zinc (anode) can hold on to them so the zinc loses its electrons 2 per atom to be exact creating a ZnSO4 with a +2 oxidation state the electrons transfer through the wire to the copper where they attach themselves to a CuSO4 and turning it into a Cu and a SO4.

Dear King of Random,
I love your initiatives and curiosity in RANDOM science and I have a fun experiment for you which I saw at an exhibition.

Join two tubes with one end on each wider than the other end.
Connect them in such a way that you can pass air in each separately as well as allow air to flow from one to another.
Then, using a soap solution, make bubbles on both wide mouths of the pipes. Then inflate each balloon separately such that one bubble is noticeably larger than the other bubble, but both have substantial size.
Now, the moment of truth. If you connect both bubbles through the pipe then you will see results contrary to your expectations.
AIR WILL FLOW FROM SMALLER TO LARGER BUBBLE, NOT LARGER TO SMALLER.

Hope you like this experiment.

It is very, very, very important that you are careful when heating water in a microwave. You need to choose a bowl or glass that is not straight, smooth edges. It is also recommended that you put like one of the wooden skewers in the glass to allow for bubbles to form.

The reason is that if it gets too hot then it can superboil. What this means is that the water is heated over the boiling point but was not able to create bubbles. When you disturb the water it will violently start bubbling (at this point, it's not a bubble, but a geyser of steam and very hot water) .
